poem:
**Geminids Over Australia**

In the quiet hours  
before dawn's blush,  
stars spill  
through the canvas of night—  
fragmented lights,  
fiery whispers,  
stitch the sky  
over dreaming lands.  
From earth's deep brow  
we watch,  
caught in the fleeting dance,  
eyes tracing  
the brief, luminous touch—  
celestial echoes  
that vanish  
before ever taking shape.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Geminid meteor shower: when to best see Australia’s biggest shooting star show this weekend Australia will see its best and biggest meteor shower of the year when the Geminids meteors light up the sky early on Saturday. Here’s when and where to look out for the shooting stars. When will the meteor shower be? The meteor shower will be strongest between 2am and 4am on Saturday morning, with the best time to watch varying depending". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
